senses.de: A folder or box for holding loose papers that are organized.
senses.ex: Please, submit your documents in a file.

Tips.title: Physical Storage
Tips.description: Refers to tangible paper organization methods, not digital.
Tips.example: Could you retrieve the client's file from the cabinet?

Tips.title: Professional Term
Tips.description: Commonly used in office and administrative settings for paperwork handling.
Tips.example: Please file these documents before you leave today.

senses.de: Submit (a legal document, application, or charge) to be placed on record by the appropriate authority.
senses.ex: She filed a lawsuit against the company.

Tips.title: Legal Action
Tips.description: Often used in legal contexts to begin formal processes or complaints.
Tips.example: He decided to file for divorce.

Tips.title: First Step
Tips.description: Indicates the initial action in a series of legal procedures.
Tips.example: The first thing to do is file the form with the court.

senses.de: Use a file to smooth or remove rough edges or small amounts from something.
senses.ex: She filed her nails before leaving for the party.

Tips.title: Manual Labor
Tips.description: Involves a physical action to shape or finish materials by hand.
Tips.example: The carpenter filed the wood to make it smooth.

Tips.title: Fine Adjustment
Tips.description: Used for precise shaping or subtle removal, not large-scale changes.
Tips.example: Carefully file the edges until the two pieces fit together.

senses.de: A tool with a rough surface for smoothing or removing small amounts from something
senses.ex: He used a file to sharpen the knife.

Tips.title: Specific Tool
Tips.description: Relates to a hand tool, not machinery or digital objects.
Tips.example: His toolkit includes several types of files for woodworking.

Tips.title: Craftsmanship
Tips.description: Associated with careful work, often in arts or trades.
Tips.example: She took a file to smooth the sculpture's rough surfaces.

senses.de: A set of data in a computer, treated as a unit by the operating system.
senses.ex: Save the document as a file.

Tips.title: Digital Item
Tips.description: Refers to a collection of digital information, not physical papers.
Tips.example: Download the file from the email attachment.

Tips.title: Computer Context
Tips.description: Used in relation to computers, smartphones, or digital storage devices.
Tips.example: Remember to back up your files to prevent data loss.

Tips.title: Many Formats
Tips.description: Comes in various types like .doc, .pdf, .jpg for different content.
Tips.example: Please save the image as a .png file.

senses.de: Arrange (documents) in convenient order for storage or reference.
senses.ex: The secretary filed all the letters alphabetically.

Tips.title: Organization System
Tips.description: About creating a system to find documents easily later.
Tips.example: File the contracts in the 'completed' folder for easy access.

Tips.title: Regular Maintenance
Tips.description: Routine part of office work to keep documents organized over time.
Tips.example: End each week by filing any new paperwork on your desk.

Archive.wordDefinition:
Archive describes a collection of important, historical or valuable documents or information that are carefully preserved and protected for future generations.

Archives can contain museums, historical societies, or government institutions, and they can hold anything from old photographs to ancient manuscripts.

A file is a container for digital or physical documents that are organized and stored for future use, while an archive is a collection of significant or precious documents that are preserved for historical or reference purposes.

Catalogue.wordDefinition:
A catalogue is a list or collection of items arranged systematically, often with descriptions or pictures. It's usually used to showcase products for sale or to categorize items for easy reference.

For example, a clothing store might have a catalogue of all its merchandise to make it easier for customers to browse and order from.

A catalogue is a list of items for display or reference, while a file is a document or collection of data for storage and organization.

Document.wordDefinition:
A document is a physical or digital record that contains information, such as text or images. It could be a letter, report, or presentation.

A file is a container for storing documents or other types of data.

In simpler terms, a document is the content while a file is the container that holds the content. For example, a word processing document is the text, while the file is the document saved to your computer’s hard drive.

Documents are applicable in situations where you need to create or record something, such as in school or at work. Files are applicable when you need to store or organize documents or data on your computer or online.

Dossier.wordDefinition:
Both dossier and file are used to refer to a collection of papers or documents.

However, the word dossier typically refers to a collection of documents or information regarding a particular person, organization, or subject that is compiled for reference or analysis.

For example, a detective might gather a dossier on a suspect in a criminal investigation.

Dossier is commonly used in situations where there is organized and detailed documentation related to a particular thing or person, while file is a more general term for a collection of documents.

Folder.wordDefinition:
A folder is a container that can hold multiple files.

Think of a file as a piece of paper with writing on it, and a folder as a filing cabinet that can hold multiple pieces of paper.

Just like you would use a filing cabinet to organize and store multiple documents, you would use a folder on your computer to organize and store multiple files.

Files are applicable for things like individual documents, photos, or videos, while folders are applicable for organizing those files into different categories or topics.

For example, you might have a folder called "School" where you store all your documents and assignments related to your classes, and within that folder, you might have subfolders for each class.

In short, files hold individual pieces of information, while folders organize and store multiple files.

Inventory.wordDefinition:
Inventory usually refers to a list or record of all the items or products that a business has in stock. Inventories are essential in managing and tracking the products that are bought and sold by a company.

For example, a grocery store would keep an inventory of all the items they have in stock, including their quantities, so that they know when they need to reorder and restock.

In summary, while both file and inventory relate to organizing and keeping records, the former is more applicable to documents or papers, while the latter is more relevant to goods, products, or physical items.

Record.wordDefinition:
A record refers to a single piece of information or data that is stored and maintained in a file. For example, in a record of student grades, each student's grade is considered a record.

In simpler terms, a file is like a book that contains several chapters or sections, while a record is like a sentence or a single piece of information within each chapter or section.

In practice, you might use the term file when talking about a collection of records, and record when discussing a single piece of information within that collection.

Register.wordDefinition:
Register can refer to a list or record that is kept to track information or events, like a register of employee attendance or a register of customer purchases.

File is more commonly used in the context of documents or data storage, while register is more commonly used in the context of tracking information or events.
